text: I'm the wrist slave DealBook for the New
York Times and what could be the largest
IPO in history GM is set to go public
this week now here with us with some
analysis is Germany animal he's of
edmunds com thanks again for joining us
germy so talking about where the market
is today you know GM recently upped its
offering so where is investor demand
right now how would you characterize
that well it seems very very strong
actually and think about the events that
have led up to this you know when you're
doing an IPO it's very very important
that a company has a good story they've
got to get the fundamentals right but
there is a marketing element to this as
well and i think that the GM roadshow
teams this two of them have done a good
job in terms of orchestrating kind of a
drumbeat of positive good news really
going back over the last couple months
so it's really kind of the way they've
sold it so far but what about the actual
operations of the company they recently
reported earnings roughly two billion
and profit seems to be doing well in
China what do you think about GM as a
company well those are two high points
you know the china sales of doing very
very well they're also doing very very
well in in brazil they've had a
surprisingly strong sales in october the
third quarter results were very positive
so there's been some some some great
momentum in terms of the news that's
been coming out it a little bit ironic i
think some of the things that are
actually propelling them forward today
were started under the chairmanship the
CEO Rick Wagoner particularly the global
strategy but then also this product turn
around you know he hired Bob Lutz and I
think Bob deserves a lot of credit for
some of the great vehicles that they've
been introducing really going back now
quite a few years yeah Malcolm Gladwell
recently talked about that in The New
Yorker talking about the other side of
this equation now the government
obviously has a big hand in General
Motors today and tax parents want to
know will they actually be able to get a
lot of their money back you know around
50 billion or so was put into Jannah so
what do you think about the government's
chances of actually making a decent dime
off of this well it was very very
controversial but I think when you look
at the numbers today the odds that the
taxpayer will get reimbursed in full are
actually looking brighter and brighter
so still a lot of risk I mean the car
industry isn't incredibly competitive
and that's
going to change but I think from what
we're seeing with the IPO that this
initial offering will do you know do a
pretty good job in terms of getting the
government's take down and then over the
next few years with any luck at all we
should be able to get fully repaid fully
repaid or maybe close like ninety
percent repaid I think well you know
there's trade-offs here so the
government I think has a better chance
of fully recouping the taxpayer
investment if it's more patient so if
you're trying to liquidate the shares
more quickly that's going to put
obviously downward pressure on the share
price and could minimize the recovery I
don't see any big rush behind this I
think there was a bit of a rush to get
the IPO out obviously that's going
pretty well but it's not like the
government you know really needs the
liquidity right now it's not like they
need the money and I would urge caution
because I think if we're patient we're
more likely to get the you know even a
little bit of profit on the investment
hmm it's true now looking further out
into 2011 there's another IPO on the
horizon and that's the Chrysler I do and
a lot of people said that this does seem
to bode well for that IPO as well what
do you think this means for Chrysler
well that's an interesting point because
one of the things I think that's helping
GM right now is the fact that short ford
shares have done very well particularly
since they announced in since GM
announced the IPO this has got to create
a positive buzz the positive halo around
a potential Chrysler IPO as well but
truthfully the work to be done at
Chrysler is is still pretty extensive
they've done a great job of cutting
costs they're just introducing some new
product into the marketplace but I think
as we're seeing with GM you know at the
end of the day a turnaround has to be
propelled by top-line growth as well as
just managing costs and that's still a
sort of an unfinished story at Chrysler
yeah and stepping back you just
mentioned the name for it and for it is
done fairly well I mean they were able
to weather the recession better than
their peers in Detroit so how would you
say GM is stacked up against Ford right
now well Ford is really further along I
think in the turnaround they have to say
they really got very very lucky by
raising a lot of liquidity back when
liquidity was easy to raise really
before the financial meltdown that's
held them in good stead through the
downturn but they've also had now pretty
consistent pretty stable management team
really led by alan mulally and they've
been executing to
a the same plan flawlessly for about
four to five years so they've just had a
lot more time for the turnaround plan to
to kick in and and to bear fruit so with
with GM we're about a year into that
process we've got a new CEO but the next
level down management teams been in
place for a little while and that it's
that stability I think with Ford that's
really been helping them yes
accessibility and forward and more
stability hopefully with GM and Chrysler
as you see it thanks so much for joining
us Jeremy once again that was germy
animal of edmunds com I'm Evelyn Rusli
